user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_parse_arguments_:
```c
enum MHD_Result
MHD_parse_arguments_ (struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                      enum MHD_ValueKind kind,
                      char *args,
                      MHD_ArgumentIterator_ cb,
                      void *cls)
{
  struct MHD_Daemon *daemon = connection->daemon;
  char *equals;
  char *amper;

  while ( (NULL != args) &&
          ('\0' != args[0]) )
  {
    size_t key_len;
    size_t value_len;
    equals = strchr (args, '=');
    amper = strchr (args, '&');
    if (NULL == amper)
    {
      /* last argument */
      if (NULL == equals)
      {
        /* last argument, without '=' */
        MHD_unescape_plus (args);
        key_len = daemon->unescape_callback (daemon->unescape_callback_cls,
                                             connection,
                                             args);
        if (MHD_NO == cb (cls,
                          args,
                          key_len,
                          NULL,
                          0,
                          kind))
          return MHD_NO;
        break;
      }
      /* got 'foo=bar' */
      equals[0] = '\0';
      equals++;
      MHD_unescape_plus (args);
      key_len = daemon->unescape_callback (daemon->unescape_callback_cls,
                                           connection,
                                           args);
      MHD_unescape_plus (equals);
      value_len = daemon->unescape_callback (daemon->unescape_callback_cls,
                                             connection,
                                             equals);
      if (MHD_NO == cb (cls,
                        args,
                        key_len,
                        equals,
                        value_len,
                        kind))
        return MHD_NO;
      break;
    }
    /* amper is non-NULL here */
    amper[0] = '\0';
    amper++;
    if ( (NULL == equals) ||
         (equals >= amper) )
    {
      /* got 'foo&bar' or 'foo&bar=val', add key 'foo' with NULL for value */
      MHD_unescape_plus (args);
      key_len = daemon->unescape_callback (daemon->unescape_callback_cls,
                                           connection,
                                           args);
      if (MHD_NO == cb (cls,
                        args,
                        key_len,
                        NULL,
                        0,
                        kind))
        return MHD_NO;
      /* continue with 'bar' */
      args = amper;
      continue;
    }
    /* equals and amper are non-NULL here, and equals < amper,
 so we got regular 'foo=value&bar...'-kind of argument */
    equals[0] = '\0';
    equals++;
    MHD_unescape_plus (args);
    key_len = daemon->unescape_callback (daemon->unescape_callback_cls,
                                         connection,
                                         args);
    MHD_unescape_plus (equals);
    value_len = daemon->unescape_callback (daemon->unescape_callback_cls,
                                           connection,
                                           equals);
    if (MHD_NO == cb (cls,
                      args,
                      key_len,
                      equals,
                      value_len,
                      kind))
      return MHD_NO;
    args = amper;
  }
  return MHD_YES;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I examined the entire function for compiler-specific language extensions that are commonly documented as extensions (e.g. GCC/Clang attributes like __attribute__((...)), statement expressions ({ ... }), typeof, nested functions, inline asm, builtin/__builtin_*, designated initializers with compiler-specific forms, zero-length arrays, anonymous structs/unions as extensions, token-pasting quirks, or other non-standard tokens such as __extension__ or compiler-specific keywords). The code only uses standard C constructs and standard library functions (enum, struct pointers, char*, size_t, NULL, strchr, plain function-pointer callback invocation, standard control flow and pointer operations). There are no uses of compiler-specific keywords, builtins, attributes, or other explicit language extensions documented by compilers. Therefore no fragments need to be investigated for MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2.
